Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: A surface charge driven nanofluidic pump

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1335946
Prakash

The over-arching goal of this proposal is to provide transformative advances towards developing a nanofluidic pump inspired by principles of active pumping from biology and engineered nanofluidics. In this proof-of-concept project, an attempt will be made to establish electrokinetic aqueous electrolyte transport in a confined nanochannel in the presence of asymmetric surface charges on the channel walls. The experiments will be guided by computational models (both continuum and molecular dynamics) to engineer a proof-of-concept, novel, nanofluidic pump. The idea is based on well-established ideas in biological systems that use asymmetric charges to move hydrated ions and combine with a nanofluidic device with embedded electrodes to develop a novel nanofluidic pump. Since, no such system has been built before this proposal presents high risk, potentially transformative research. This work will have significant impact on advances in nanoscale fluid dynamics leading to new avenues for engineering novel nanofluidic devices for a variety of applications as described in the main proposal narrative. By using multi-stage integration between research and education, this multi-disciplinary experimental project is expected to give at a minimum undergraduate and graduate students and perhaps a much broader audience including minority, under-represented groups, middle and high school female students exposure to microfluidics and nanofluidics through individual and group lab training, coursework, hands-on workshops, outreach, and web modules for impact on education of future scientists and engineers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major advances to the field of nanofluidics include demonstrations of a three state nanofluidic switch and one of the first reports on cation dependent transport in gated nanochannels. To our knowledge, this work presents a viable path for tunable control of ionic transport by systematic manipulation of the gate potential.

We hypothesize that the switching behavior alters the concentrations of ionic species and the electric field within the nanochannel. Development of a current switch represents a key addition to the existing ionic circuit elements towards the development of fluidic logic circuits and has not been previously demonstrated. Additionally, the preferential transport of monovalent cations with respect to divalent cations was also demonstrated. The gate electrode modulates the surface potential and this the concentration of carriers and the electric field in the nanochannel, enhancing or diminishing the preferential transport. Ion dependent transport and the ability to control cation transport via embedded gate electrode(s) is considered an essential step for applications such as DNA detection and realization of artificial ion channels and ion pumps.

The work supported by NSF also contributed to training of two students successfuly completing their MS and PhD degrees. The training of these students presents a tangible contribution of enhacing the technically trained human force in the US due to NSF support.

 


Last Modified: 05/02/2016
Modified by: Shaurya Prakash
